23.verse: “·Make chains for captives [Prepare/Forge the chains], because the land is full of bloody crimes and the city is full of violence.

I will ·punish [deal with] them for the way they have lived. The way they have judged others is the way I will judge them. Then they will know that I am the LORD.”

1.verse: Ezekiel’s Vision of Jerusalem - It was the sixth year [since king Jehoiachin’s exile (1:2)], on the fifth day of the sixth month [September 17, 592 BC; this vision is the subject of chapters 8–11]. I was sitting in my house with the elders of Judah in front of me. There ·I felt the power of the Lord GOD [the hand of the LORD GOD came upon me].

2.verse: I looked and saw something that looked like a ·human [man]. From the waist down it looked like fire, and from the waist up it looked like bright glowing ·metal [or amber].

3.verse: ·It [or He] stretched out the shape of a hand and caught me by the hair on my head. ·The Spirit [or A spirit; or The wind] lifted me up between the earth and ·the sky [heaven]. He took me in visions of God to Jerusalem, to the entrance to the north gate of the inner courtyard of the Temple. 5.verse: Then he said to me, “·Human [Son of man; 2:1], now look toward the north.” So I looked up toward the north, and in the entrance north of the gate of the altar was the ·idol that caused God to be jealous [image of jealousy].

6.verse: He said to me, “·Human [Son of man; 2:1], do you see what they are doing? 11.verse: Standing in front of these carvings and idols were seventy of the elders of [the house of] Israel and Jaazaniah son of Shaphan. Each man had his ·pan for burning incense [censer] in his hand, and a ·sweet-smelling [fragrant] cloud of incense was rising.

12.verse: Then he said to me, “·Human [Son of man; 2:1], have you seen what the elders of [the house of] Israel are doing in the dark? Have you seen each man in the ·room [chamber; shrine] of his own ·idol [carved image]? They say, ‘The LORD doesn’t see us. The LORD has ·left [abandoned; forsaken] the land.’”

14.verse: Then he brought me to the entrance of the north gate of the ·Temple [house] of the LORD, where I saw women sitting and crying for Tammuz [a Babylonian god of fertility and rain, whose annual death marked the change of seasons].

15.verse: He said to me, “Do you see, ·human [son of man; 2:1]? You will see things even more ·hateful [detestable; abominable] than these.”

16.verse: Then he brought me into the inner courtyard of the ·Temple [house of the LORD]. There I saw about twenty-five men at the entrance to the ·Temple [house] of the LORD, between the ·porch [portico] and the altar. With their backs turned to the Temple of the LORD, they faced east and were worshiping the sun in the east.

17.verse: He said to me, “Do you see, ·human [son of man; 2:1]? Is it ·unimportant [a trivial thing] that the ·people [house] of Judah are doing the ·hateful [detestable; abominable] things they have done here? They have filled the land with violence and ·made me continually angry [provoked me to still greater anger]. ·Look [Behold], they are ·insulting me every way they can [putting the branch to their nose; perhaps part of the worship of the sun god].

18.verse: So I will act ·in anger [with wrath]. I will have no pity, nor will I ·show mercy [spare them]. Even if they shout in my ears, I won’t listen to them.”

1.verse: Vision of the Angels - Then he shouted with a loud voice in my ears, “You who are ·chosen [appointed] to ·punish [execute judgment on] this city, come near with your ·weapon [weapon of destruction] in your hand.”

2.verse: Then six men came from the direction of the upper gate, which faces north, each with his ·powerful weapon [war club] in his hand. Among them was a man dressed in linen with a writing case at his side. The men went in and stood by the bronze altar [Ex. 27:1–8].

3.verse: Then the glory of the God of Israel [his manifest presence] went up from above the ·creatures with wings [cherubim], where it had been, to the place in the ·Temple where the door opened [threshold of the house]. He called to the man dressed in linen who had the writing case at his side.

7.verse: Then he said to the men, “·Make the Temple unclean [Defile the temple; ritually], and fill the courtyards with ·those who have been killed [the slain]. Go out!” So the men went out and killed the people in the city.

8.verse: While they were ·killing the people [striking them down], I was left alone. I bowed facedown on the ground and I cried out, “Oh, Lord GOD! Will you destroy ·everyone left alive in [the whole remnant of] Israel when you ·turn loose your anger [pour out your wrath] on Jerusalem?”

9.verse: Then he said to me, “The sin of the ·people [house] of Israel and Judah is very great. The land is filled with people who murder, and the city is full of ·people who are not fair [injustice; corruption]. The people say, ‘The LORD has ·left [abandoned; forsaken] the land, and the LORD does not see.’

10.verse: But ·I [my eye] will have no pity, nor will I ·show mercy [spare]. I will bring their ·evil [deeds; way] back on their heads.”

1.verse: The Coals of Fire - Then I looked and ·saw [behold] in the ·dome [vault; expanse; or platform; 1:22] above the heads of the ·living creatures [cherubim] something like a ·sapphire [or lapis lazuli] gem which looked like a throne.

3.verse: Now the ·living creatures [cherubim] were standing on the south side of the ·Temple [house] when the man went in. And a cloud filled the inner courtyard.

4.verse: Then the glory of the LORD [his manifest presence] went up from the ·living creatures [cherubim] and stood over the ·door [threshold] of the ·Temple [house]. 7.verse: ·One living creature [The cherub] put out his hand to the fire that was among them, took some of the fire, and put it in the hands of the man dressed in linen. Then the man took the fire and went out.

9.verse: I ·saw [looked and saw/behold] the four wheels by the ·living creatures [cherubim], one wheel by each ·living creature [cherub]. The wheels looked like shining ·chrysolite [or topaz; or beryl].

14.verse: Each ·living creature [one] had four faces. The first face was the face of a ·creature with wings [cherub]. The second face was a ·human [man’s] face, the third was the face of a lion, and the fourth was the face of an eagle.

15.verse: Then the ·living creatures [cherubim] ·flew [mounted; rose] up. They were the same living creatures I had seen by the Kebar ·River [Canal; 1:1].

16.verse: When the ·living creatures [cherubim] moved, the wheels moved beside them. When the ·living creatures [cherubim] lifted their wings to fly up from the ground, the wheels did not leave their place beside them.

18.verse: Then the glory of the LORD [his manifest presence] left the ·door [threshold] of the ·Temple [house] and stood over the ·living creatures [cherubim].

19.verse: ·As I watched [Before my eyes], the ·living creatures [cherubim] spread their wings and flew up from the ·ground [earth], with the wheels beside them. They stood where the east gate of the ·Temple [house] of the LORD opened, and the glory of the God of Israel was over them.

1.verse: Prophecies Against Evil Leaders - ·The Spirit [or A spirit/or wind] lifted me up and brought me to the ·front [eastern] gate of the ·Temple [house] of the LORD, which faces east. ·I saw [And behold] twenty-five men at the entrance of the gate, among them Jaazaniah son of Azzur and Pelatiah son of Benaiah, who were ·leaders [princes; officials] of the people.

22.verse: Ezekiel’s Vision Ends - Then the ·living creatures [cherubim] lifted their wings with the wheels beside them, and the glory of the God of Israel [his manifest presence] was above them.

11.verse: Say, ‘I am a sign to you.’ “The same things I have done will be done to the people in Jerusalem. They will be taken ·away from their country [into exile] as captives.

9.verse: ·I will punish [My hand will be against] the prophets who see false visions and ·prophesy lies [utter lying divinations]. They will ·have no place among [not be in the council of] my people. 14.verse: I will tear down the wall on which you put whitewash. I will level it to the ground so that ·people will see the wall’s foundation [its foundations will be laid bare/exposed]. And when the wall falls, you will ·be destroyed [perish] ·under [or within] it. Then you will know that I am the LORD.

15.verse: So I will ·carry out my anger [spend my wrath/rage] on the wall and against those who covered it with whitewash. Then I will tell you, “The wall is gone, and those who covered it with whitewash are gone.

16.verse: The prophets of Israel who prophesy ·to [or about] Jerusalem and who see visions of peace for the city, when there is no peace, will be gone, says the Lord GOD.”’

17.verse: False Women Prophets - “Now, ·human [son of man; 2:1], look toward the ·women among [daughters of] your people who ·make up their own prophecies [prophesy from their own hearts/imaginations]. Prophesy against them.

18.verse: Say, ‘This is what the Lord GOD says: ·How terrible it will be for [Woe to the] women who sew ·magic charms [bands] on their wrists and make ·veils [or headbands] of every length to trap people! 20.verse: “‘So this is what the Lord GOD says: I am against your magic ·charms [bands], by which you ·trap [ensnare; hunt] ·people [souls] as if they were birds. I will tear ·those charms [them] off your arms, and I will free those ·people [souls] you have ·trapped [ensnare; hunt] like birds.

21.verse: I will also tear off your ·veils [or headbands] and save my people from your hands. They will no longer be ·trapped by your power [prey in your hand]. Then you will know that I am the LORD.

You will not ·come back from there [or be inhabited] or have any place in the ·world [land] of the living again.

21.verse: ·Other people will be afraid of what happened to you [or I will bring you to a terrible end], and it will be the end of you. People will look for you, but they will never find you again, says the Lord GOD.”

1.verse: A Funeral Song for Tyre - The ·LORD spoke his word [word of the LORD came] to me, saying:

2.verse: “·Human [Son of man; 2:1], sing a ·funeral song [lament; dirge] for the city of Tyre.

3.verse: Speak to Tyre, which ·has ports for the Mediterranean Sea [sits at the gateway to the Sea] and is a ·place for trade [merchant] for the people of many coastlands. ‘This is what the Lord GOD says: Tyre, you have said, “I am ·like a beautiful ship [perfect in beauty].”

4.verse: ·You were at home on [Your borders were in the heart of] the high seas. Your builders made your beauty perfect.

5.verse: They made all your boards of fir trees from ·Mount Hermon [Senir]. They took a cedar tree from Lebanon to make a ship’s mast for you.

6.verse: They made your oars from oak trees from Bashan. They made your deck from cypress trees from the coast of ·Cyprus [Kittim] ·and set ivory into it [inlaid with ivory].

7.verse: Your sail of ·linen with designs sewed on it [embroidered linen] came from Egypt and ·became like a flag for you [served as your banner]. Your ·cloth shades over the deck [awnings] were blue and purple and came from the ·island [coastlands] of ·Cyprus [Elisha; a city on the east side of Cyprus and an older name for the island].

8.verse: ·Men [Residents; or Leaders] from Sidon [a major city twenty-five miles north of Tyre] and Arvad [a city on the Phoenician coast, north of Sidon] used oars to row you. Tyre, your skilled men were ·the sailors [or captains; pilots] on your deck.

9.verse: ·Workers [or Veteran craftsmen; Elders] of Byblos were with you, putting caulk in your ship’s seams. All the ships of the sea and their sailors came alongside to trade with you.

10.verse: “‘Men of Persia, ·Lydia [Lud; a city in Asia Minor], and ·Put [present-day Libya, in North Africa] were warriors in your ·navy [army] and hung their shields and helmets on your sides. They ·made you look beautiful [gave you splendor].

11.verse: Men of Arvad [v. 8] and ·Cilicia [Helech; southeast Asia Minor] guarded your city walls all around. Men of Gammad [an unknown location, perhaps northern Asia Minor] were in your watchtowers and hung their shields around your walls. They made your beauty perfect.

12.verse: “‘People of Tarshish [probably in southern Spain; Jonah 1:3] became traders for you because of your great wealth. They ·traded [exchanged] your goods for silver, iron, tin, and lead.

13.verse: “‘People of ·Greece [Javan], Tubal, and Meshech [both in Asia Minor; 32:26] became merchants for you. They traded your goods for slaves and items of bronze.

14.verse: “‘People of Beth Togarmah [eastern Asia Minor; present-day Armenia] traded your goods for ·work [or chariot] horses, war horses [either chariot of cavalry horses], and mules.

15.verse: “‘·People of [Sons of] Rhodes [an island off southwest coast of Asia Minor] became merchants for you, selling your goods on many coastlands. They brought back ivory tusks and ·valuable black wood [ebony] as your payment.

16.verse: “‘People of Aram [Syria] ·became traders for [did business with] you, because you had so many good things to sell. They traded your goods for turquoise, purple cloth, ·cloth with designs sewed on [embroidered work], fine linen, coral, and rubies.

17.verse: “‘People of Judah and Israel became merchants for you. They traded your goods for wheat from Minnith [a town in Ammon, east of the Jordan River], and for ·meal [millet], honey, olive oil, and balm.

18.verse: “‘People of Damascus [the capital of Aram (Syria)] became traders for you because you have many good things and great wealth. They traded your goods for wine from Helbon [a town north of Damascus], wool from Zahar [an area northwest of Damascus], and barrels of wine from Izal [possibly present-day Yemen]. They received wrought iron, cassia [a tree similar to the cinnamon tree; Ex. 30:24], and ·sugar cane [or calamus; a fragrant reed] in payment for your ·good things [wares; merchandise].

19.verse: “‘People of Damascus [the capital of Aram (Syria)] became traders for you because you have many good things and great wealth. They traded your goods for wine from Helbon [a town north of Damascus], wool from Zahar [an area northwest of Damascus], and barrels of wine from Izal [possibly present-day Yemen]. They received wrought iron, cassia [a tree similar to the cinnamon tree; Ex. 30:24], and ·sugar cane [or calamus; a fragrant reed] in payment for your ·good things [wares; merchandise].

20.verse: “‘People of Dedan [a territory in southern Edom] became merchants for you, trading saddle blankets for riding.

21.verse: “‘People of Arabia and all the ·rulers [princes] of Kedar became traders for you. They received lambs, ·male sheep [rams], and goats in payment for you.

22.verse: “‘The merchants of Sheba [the southwestern Arabian peninsula, present-day Yemen] and Raamah [a city in southern Arabia] became merchants for you. They traded your goods for all the best spices, ·valuable gems [precious stones], and gold.

23.verse: “‘People of Haran [a city in present-day eastern Turkey], Canneh [unknown location], Eden [in Mesopotamia near Haran], and the traders of Sheba [v. 22], Asshur [a city south of Nineveh], and Kilmad [an unknown location] became merchants for you.

24.verse: They were paid with the best clothes, blue cloth, ·cloth with designs sewed on [embroidered work], carpets of many colors, ·and tightly wound ropes [or rolled up and tied with cords; or made of tightly knotted cords].

25.verse: “‘·Trading ships [or The ships of Tarshish] carried ·the things you sold [your merchandise]. You were like a ship full of heavy cargo in the ·middle [heart] of the sea.

26.verse: The men who rowed you brought you out into the high seas, but the east wind broke you to pieces in the ·middle [heart] of the sea.

27.verse: Your wealth, your ·trade [products], your goods, your seamen, your ·sailors [or captains], your ·workers [or caulkers], your traders, your ·warriors [soldiers], and everyone else on board sank into the ·sea [heart of the sea] on the day ·your ship was wrecked [of your fall].

28.verse: The ·people on the shore shake with fear [countryside shakes; or waves surge] when your ·sailors [or captains] cry out.

29.verse: All the men who row ·leave [disembark from; or abandon] their ships; the seamen and the ·sailors [or captains] of other ships stand on the shore.

30.verse: They cry loudly about you; they cry ·very much [bitterly]. They throw dust on their heads and roll in ashes.

31.verse: They shave their heads for you, and they put on ·rough cloth [burlap; sackcloth; signs of sorrow and distress]. They ·cry and sob for you [weep over you with bitter souls]; they ·cry loudly [mourn bitterly].

32.verse: And in their ·loud crying [wailing] they sing a ·funeral song [lament; dirge] for you: “·No one was ever destroyed [Who was…?] like Tyre, ·surrounded by [or like a tower in the middle of; or now silent in the midst of] the sea.”

33.verse: When the goods you traded went out over the seas, you ·met the needs of [satisfied] many nations. With your great wealth and ·goods [merchandise], you made kings of the earth rich.

34.verse: But now you are ·broken [shipwrecked; shattered] by the sea ·and have sunk to the bottom [in the depths of the waters]. Your ·goods [merchandise] and all the people on board have gone down with you.

35.verse: All those who live along the ·shore [coastland] are ·shocked [appalled; aghast] by what happened to you. Their kings are ·terribly afraid [horrified], and their faces ·show their fear [are troubled/contorted].

36.verse: The traders among the nations hiss at you. You have ·come to a terrible end [or become a horror], and you are gone forever.’”

1.verse: Prophecy Against the King of Tyre - The ·LORD spoke his word [word of the LORD came] to me, saying:

2.verse: “·Human [Son of man; 2:1], say to the ruler of Tyre: ‘This is what the Lord GOD says: Because ·you are [your heart is] proud, you say, “I am a god. I sit on the ·throne [seat] of a god in the ·middle [heart] of the seas.” You think you are as wise as a god, but you are a ·human [mortal; man], not a god.

3.verse: [Look; Behold] You ·think you are [are] wiser than Daniel [14:14]. ·You think you can find out all secrets [No secret is hidden from you].

4.verse: Through your wisdom and understanding you have made yourself rich. You have ·gained [gathered] gold and silver ·and have saved it in [in] your ·storerooms [treasuries].

5.verse: Through your great skill in trading, you have made your riches grow. ·You are too [Your heart is] proud because of your riches.

6.verse: “‘So this is what the Lord GOD says: [Because] You think you are wise like a god,

7.verse: ·but [therefore, look/behold] I will bring foreign people against you, the ·cruelest [most ruthless] nations. They will draw their swords ·and destroy all that your wisdom has built [against your beauty and wisdom], and they will ·dishonor [defile] your ·greatness [splendor].

8.verse: They will ·kill you [bring you down to the pit]; you will die a ·terrible [violent] death ·like those who are killed at sea [or in the heart of the sea].

9.verse: ·While they are killing you [In the presence of those killing you], ·you will not [will you…?] be able to say anymore, “I am a god.” You will be only a human, not a god, ·when your murderers kill you [in the hands of those who kill you].

10.verse: You will die ·like an unclean person [the death of the uncircumcised]; ·foreigners will kill you […in the hands of strangers/foreigners]. I have spoken, says the Lord GOD.’”

11.verse: The ·LORD spoke his word [word of the LORD came] to me, saying:

12.verse: “·Human [Son of man; 2:1], sing a ·funeral song [lament; dirge] for the king of Tyre. Say to him: ‘This is what the Lord GOD says: You were ·an example [the seal/signet] of what was perfect, full of wisdom and perfect in beauty.

13.verse: You ·had a wonderful life, as if you were in Eden [were in Eden], the garden of God [like Adam; Gen. 1—2]. Every valuable gem ·was on [covered] you: ·ruby [or carnelian], ·topaz [or chysolite], and ·emerald [or diamond], ·yellow quartz [or chrysolite], onyx, and jasper, ·sapphire [or lapis lazuli], turquoise, and ·chrysolite [or beryl; or emerald]. Your ·jewelry [settings and mounts] was made of gold. It was prepared on the day you were created.

14.verse: I appointed a ·living creature [cherub] to guard you. I put you on the holy mountain of God. You walked among the ·gems that shined like fire [fiery stones].

15.verse: ·Your life was right and good [You were blameless in your ways] from the day you were created, until ·evil [wickedness; unrighteousness] was found in you.

16.verse: Because you traded with countries ·far away [or in abundance], you ·learned to be cruel [were filled with violence], and you sinned. So I ·threw you down [banished you] in ·disgrace [or defilement] from the mountain of God. And the ·living creature [cherub] who guarded you ·forced you out [expelled you] from among the ·gems that shined like fire [fiery stones].

17.verse: ·You became too [Your heart was] proud because of your beauty. You ·ruined [corrupted] your wisdom because of your ·greatness [splendor]. I threw you down to the ground. ·Your example taught a lesson to [or I made a spectacle of you before] other kings.

18.verse: You ·dishonored [desecrated; profaned; ritually] your ·places of worship [sanctuaries] through your many sins and dishonest trade. So I ·set on fire the place where you lived [sent fire out from your midst], and the fire ·burned you up [consumed you]. I turned you into ashes on the ground ·for all those watching to see [before the eyes of all who saw you].

19.verse: All the nations who knew you are ·shocked [appalled; aghast] about you. Your punishment was so terrible, and you are gone forever.’”

20.verse: Prophecy Against Sidon - The ·LORD spoke his word [word of the LORD came] to me, saying:

21.verse: “·Human [Son of man; 2:1], ·look [set your face] toward the city of Sidon and prophesy against her.

22.verse: Say: ‘This is what the Lord GOD says: I am against you, Sidon, and I will show my glory ·among [or within] you [his manifest presence]. People will know that I am the LORD when I ·have punished Sidon [execute judgments against her]; I will show my holiness ·by defeating [in] her.

23.verse: I will send ·diseases [a plague/pestilence] to Sidon, and blood will flow in her streets. ·Those who are wounded [or The slain] ·in Sidon will fall dead [will fall in her midst], ·attacked from [by the sword against it on] all sides. Then they will know that I am the LORD.

24.verse: God Will Help Israel - “‘No more will neighboring nations be like ·thorny branches [prickling briars] or sharp ·stickers [thorns] to ·hurt [treat with contempt/scorn the house of] Israel. Then they will know that I am the Lord GOD.

25.verse: “‘This is what the Lord GOD says: I will gather the ·people [house] of Israel from the nations where they are scattered. I will show my holiness ·when the nations see what I do for my people [in them in the sight of the nations]. Then they will live in their own land—the land I gave to my servant Jacob.

26.verse: They will live safely in the land and will build houses and plant vineyards. They will live in safety after I have ·punished [executed judgments against] all the nations around who ·hate them [treat them with contempt; scorn them]. Then they will know that I am the LORD their God.’”

1.verse: Prophecy Against Egypt - It was the tenth year [since King Jehoiachin’s exile (1:2)], in the tenth month, on the twelfth day of the month [January 7, 587 BC]. The ·LORD spoke his word [word of the LORD came] to me, saying:

2.verse: “·Human [Son of man; 2:1], ·look [set your face] toward the king of Egypt, and prophesy against him and all Egypt.

3.verse: Say: ‘This is what the Lord GOD says: [Look; Behold] I am against you, Pharaoh, king of Egypt. You are like a great ·crocodile [or monster; or dragon] that lies in the Nile River. You say, “The Nile is mine; I made it for myself.”

4.verse: But I will put hooks in your jaws, and I will make the fish of the Nile stick to your ·sides [scales]. I will pull you up out of your ·rivers [streams], with all the fish of your streams sticking to your ·sides [scales].

5.verse: I will leave you in the ·desert [wilderness] , you and all the fish from your ·rivers [streams]. You will fall onto the ·ground [open field]; you will not be picked up or ·buried [gathered]. I have given you to the ·wild animals [beasts of the earth] and to the birds of the sky for food.

6.verse: Then all the people who live in Egypt will know that I am the LORD. “‘·Israel tried to lean on you for help, but you were like a crutch made out of a weak stalk of grass [Because you were a reed staff for the house of Israel…; Is. 36:6].

7.verse: When their hands grabbed you, you ·splintered [broke] and tore open their shoulders. When they leaned on you, you ·broke [splintered] and made all their ·backs twist [or legs go wobbly; or loins shake].

8.verse: “‘So this is what the Lord GOD says: I will ·cause an enemy to attack [bring a sword against] you and kill your people and animals.

9.verse: Egypt will become an ·empty desert [desolate wasteland]. Then they will know that I am the LORD. “‘Because you said, “The Nile River is mine, and I have made it,”

10.verse: I am against you and your ·rivers [streams]. I will destroy the land of Egypt and make it an ·empty desert [desolate wasteland] from Migdol [in the north] to Aswan [in the south], all the way to the border of Cush [Ethiopia].

11.verse: No ·person or animal will walk [foot of man shall pass through it and no foot of beast will pass] through it, and no one will live in Egypt for forty years.

12.verse: I will make the land of Egypt ·the most deserted country of all [a desolation among desolate lands]. Her cities will be ·the most deserted of all [a desolation among] ruined cities for forty years. I will scatter the Egyptians among the nations, spreading them among the countries.

13.verse: “‘This is what the Lord GOD says: After forty years I will gather Egypt from the nations where they have been scattered.

14.verse: I will ·bring back the Egyptian captives [restore the fortunes of Egypt] and make them return to ·southern Egypt [the land of Pathros], to the land ·they came from [of their ancestry/origin]. They will become a ·weak [lowly; insignificant] kingdom there.

15.verse: It will be the ·weakest [most lowly/insignificant] kingdom, and it will never again ·rule [exalt itself over] other nations. I will make it so ·weak [small] it will never again rule over the nations.

16.verse: The Israelites will never again ·depend on [rely on; have confidence in] Egypt. Instead, ·Egypt’s punishment [it] will remind the Israelites of their sin in turning to Egypt for help. Then they will know that I am the Lord GOD.’”

17.verse: Egypt Is Given to Babylon - It was the twenty-seventh year [since King Jehoiachin’s exile (1:2)], in the first month, on the first day of the month [April 26, 571 BC]. The ·LORD spoke his word [word of the LORD came] to me, saying:

18.verse: “·Human [Son of man; 2:1], Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon made his army ·fight [labor] hard against Tyre. Every soldier’s head was rubbed bare, and every shoulder was rubbed raw. But Nebuchadnezzar and his army gained ·nothing [or no wages] from ·fighting Tyre [the labor he performed against her].

19.verse: So this is what the Lord GOD says: I will give the land of Egypt to Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon. He will ·take away Egypt’s people and its wealth and its treasures [carry off its wealth and loot and plunder it] as pay for his army.

20.verse: I am giving Nebuchadnezzar the land of Egypt as ·a reward [compensation] for working hard for me, says the Lord GOD.

21.verse: “·At that time [On that day] I will ·make Israel grow strong again [cause a horn to sprout for the house of Israel; Ps. 132:17], and I will ·let you, Ezekiel, speak to them [give you an open mouth among them]. Then they will know that I am the LORD.”

1.verse: Egypt Will Be Punished - The ·LORD spoke his word [word of the LORD came] to me, saying:

2.verse: “·Human [Son of man; 2:1], prophesy and say, ‘This is what the Lord GOD says: ·Cry [Wail] ·and say [Alas; Hah], “·The terrible day is coming […for the day].”

3.verse: [For] The day is near; the ·LORD’s day of judging [Day of the LORD] is near. It is a ·cloudy day [day of clouds; perhaps storm clouds, or indicating the presence of God; Joel 2:2; Ex. 19:9] and a time ·when the nations will be judged [for the nations].

4.verse: An ·enemy will attack [sword will come against] Egypt, and Cush [Ethiopia] will ·tremble with fear [be in anguish]. When the ·killing begins [slain fall] in Egypt, her wealth will be ·taken away [carried off], and her foundations will be torn down.

5.verse: Cush, Put, ·Lydia [Lud; 27:10], all ·Arabia [or all the foreigners; or all the mercenaries], ·Libya [Kub], and ·some of my people who had made an agreement with Egypt [or the people of allied lands; the sons of the land of the covenant] will fall ·dead in war [by the sword with them].

6.verse: “‘This is what the LORD says: ·Those who fight on Egypt’s side [Egypt’s supporters] will fall. The power she is proud of will ·be lost [collapse; come down]. From Migdol [in northern Egypt] to ·Aswan [Syene; in southern Egypt], the people will fall ·dead in war [by the sword] says the Lord GOD.

7.verse: They will be ·the most deserted [desolate in the midst of desolate] lands. Egypt’s cities will be ·the worst [in the midst] of cities that lie in ruins.

8.verse: Then they will know that I am the LORD when I set fire to Egypt and when all ·those nations on her side [her helpers/allies] are crushed.

9.verse: “‘·At that time [On that day] I will send messengers in ships to frighten Cush [Ethiopia], which ·now feels safe [is over-confident; or is complacent]. ·The people of Cush will tremble with fear [Anguish will come upon them] ·when Egypt is punished [in the day of Egypt]. And [look; behold] that time is sure to come.

10.verse: “‘This is what the Lord GOD says: I will destroy ·great numbers of people in [the hordes of] Egypt ·through the power [by the hand] of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon.

11.verse: Nebuchadnezzar and his ·army [or people], the ·cruelest army [most ruthless] of any nation, will be brought in to destroy the land. They will draw their swords against Egypt and will fill the land with ·those they kill [the slain].

12.verse: I will make the streams of the Nile River become dry land, and then I will sell the land to evil people. I will ·destroy [desolate] the land and everything in it through the ·power [hand] of foreigners. I, the LORD, have spoken.

13.verse: Egypt’s Idols Are Destroyed - “‘This is what the Lord GOD says: I will destroy the idols and ·take away [put an end to] the ·statues of gods from the city of [images in] Memphis. There will no longer be a ·leader [prince] in the land of Egypt, and I will spread fear through the land of Egypt.

14.verse: I will make ·southern Egypt [Pathros] ·empty [a desolation] and ·start a fire in [or set fire to] Zoan and ·punish [execute judgment on] Thebes.

15.verse: And I will pour out my anger against Pelusium [a fortess in the eastern delta of the Nile River], the ·strong place [stronghold] of Egypt. I will ·destroy [cut off] ·great numbers of people in [the hordes/armies of] Thebes.

16.verse: I will set fire to Egypt. Pelusium [v. 15] will ·be in great pain [writhe in agony]. ·The walls of Thebes will be broken open [Thebes will be breached], and Memphis will ·have troubles [or face enemies] every day.

17.verse: The young men of ·Heliopolis [On; six miles northeast of Cairo] and Bubastis [the capital of northern Egypt; forty miles northeast of Cairo] will fall dead ·in war [by the sword], and ·the people [or the cities; they] will be taken away as captives.

18.verse: In Tahpanhes [in northeast Egypt] the day will be dark when I break ·Egypt’s power [the yoke of Egypt]. Then ·she will no longer be proud of her power [her proud strength will cease]. A cloud will cover Egypt, and her ·villages [daughters] will be captured and taken away.

19.verse: So I will ·punish [execute judgments on] Egypt, and they will know I am the LORD.’”

20.verse: Egypt Becomes Weak - It was in the eleventh year [since King Jehoiachin’s exile (1:2)], in the first month, on the seventh day of the month [April 29, 587 BC]. The ·LORD spoke his word [word of the LORD came] to me, saying:

21.verse: “·Human [Son of man; 2:1], I have broken the ·powerful arm [arm] of Pharaoh, the king of Egypt. It has not been ·tied [bound] up, so it will not get well. It has not been wrapped with a bandage, so it will not be strong enough to hold a sword in war.

22.verse: So this is what the Lord GOD says: [Look; Behold] I am against Pharaoh, the king of Egypt. I will break his arms, both the strong arm and the broken arm, and I will make the sword fall from his hand.

23.verse: I will scatter the Egyptians among the nations, spreading them among the countries.

24.verse: I will make the arms of the king of Babylon strong and put my sword in his hand. But I will break the arms of Pharaoh. Then ·when he faces the king of Babylon [before him] he will ·cry out in pain [groan] like a ·dying [mortally wounded] person.

25.verse: So I will make the arms of the king of Babylon strong, but the arms of the king of Egypt will ·fall [become limp]. Then people will know that I am the LORD when I put my sword into the hand of the king of Babylon and he ·uses it in war [wields it; extends it] against the land of Egypt.

26.verse: Then I will scatter the Egyptians among the nations, spreading them among the countries. Then they will know that I am the LORD.”

1.verse: A Cedar Tree - It was in the eleventh year [since King Jehoiachin’s exile (1:2)], in the third month, on the first day of the month [June 21, 587 BC]. The ·LORD spoke his word [word of the LORD came] to me, saying:

2.verse: “·Human [Son of man; 2:1], say to the king of Egypt and his people: ‘·No one [Who…?] is like you in your greatness.

3.verse: [Look; Behold] Assyria was once like a cedar tree in Lebanon with beautiful branches that shaded the forest. It was ·very tall [a towering height]; its top was among the clouds.

4.verse: Much water made the tree grow; the deep springs made it tall. Rivers flowed around ·the bottom of the tree [its place of planting] and sent their ·streams [channels] to all other trees ·in the countryside [of the field].

5.verse: So the tree was taller than all the other trees ·in the countryside [of the field]. Its ·limbs [boughs] became large and its branches long because of ·so much [abundant] water.

6.verse: All the birds of the ·sky [heavens] made their nests in the tree’s ·limbs [boughs; Dan. 4:12, 21]. And all the ·wild animals [beasts of the field] gave birth under its branches. All great nations lived in the tree’s shade.

7.verse: So the tree was great and beautiful, with its long branches, because its roots reached down to ·much [abundant] water.

8.verse: The cedar trees in the garden of God [Eden] were not as great as it was. The ·pine [fir; juniper] trees ·did not have such great [could not equal its] ·limbs [boughs]. The plane trees did not have such branches. No tree in the garden of God was as beautiful as this tree.

9.verse: I made it beautiful with many branches, and all the trees of Eden in the garden of God ·wanted to be like [envied] it.

10.verse: “‘So this is what the Lord GOD says: The tree grew tall. Its top reached the clouds, and it became proud of its height.

11.verse: So I handed it ·over to [into the hand of] a mighty ruler of the nations for him to ·punish [deal with] it. Because it was ·evil [wicked], I ·got rid of it [threw it out; cast it aside].

12.verse: The ·cruelest [most ruthless] foreign nation cut it down and left it. The tree’s branches fell on the mountains and in all the valleys, and its ·broken limbs [boughs] were in all the ravines of the land. All the nations of the earth left the shade of that tree.

13.verse: The birds of the ·sky [heavens] live on the fallen tree. The wild animals live among the tree’s fallen branches.

14.verse: So the trees that grow by the water will not ·be proud to be [or grow so] tall; they will not put their tops among the clouds. None of the trees that are watered well will grow that tall, because they all are ·meant [appointed; consigned] to die and go ·under the ground [or to the underworld; to the depths of the earth]. They will be with ·people who have died [mortals; sons of men] and ·have gone down [those who descend] to the ·place of the dead [pit].

15.verse: “‘This is what the Lord GOD says: On the day ·when the tree [it; Assyria] went down to ·the place of the dead [Sheol], I ·made the deep springs cry loudly [or caused mourning]. I ·covered them [or closed the deep over it] and held back their rivers, and the great waters ·stopped flowing [were restrained]. I dressed Lebanon ·in black [or with gloom; in mourning for the great tree], and all the trees in the countryside ·were sad about it [wilted; fainted].

16.verse: I made the nations ·shake with fear [tremble; quake] at the sound of the tree falling when I brought it down to ·the place of the dead [Sheol]. It went to join those who ·have gone down [descend] to the ·grave [pit; the trees represent other great nations that have fallen]. Then all the trees of Eden and the best and ·most beautiful [choicest] trees of Lebanon, all the well-watered trees, were comforted in the ·place of the dead below the earth [underworld; world below].

18.verse: “When your people say to you, ‘Explain to us what you mean by this,’

21.verse: Say to the people, ‘This is what the Lord GOD says: [Look; Behold] I am going to take the ·people [house] of Israel from among the nations where they have gone. I will gather them from all around and bring them into their own land.

I will save them from all ·the ways they sin and turn against me [their backsliding/unfaithfulness/apostasies], and I will ·make them clean [purify them]. Then they will be my people, and I will be their God.

24.verse: “‘My servant David will be their king [34:23], and they will all have one shepherd. They will ·live by [walk in] my ·laws [rules; judgments] and be careful to keep my ·rules [statutes].

28.verse: When my ·Temple [sanctuary] is among them forever, the nations will know that I, the LORD, ·make Israel holy [sanctify Israel].’”

1.verse: Prophecy Against Gog - The ·LORD spoke his word [word of the LORD came] to me, saying,

In this way they will ·take the treasures of [plunder] those who ·took their treasures [plundered them]; they will take the loot of those who took their loot, says the Lord GOD.

17.verse: “·Human [Son of man; 2:1], this is what the Lord GOD says: Speak to every kind of bird and ·wild animal [all the beasts of the field]: ‘·Come [Assemble] together, come! ·Come together [Gather] from all around to my ·sacrifice [or slaughter], a great ·sacrifice [or slaughter] which I will prepare for you on the mountains of Israel. 21.verse: “I will ·show [display] my glory [manifest presence] among the nations. All the nations will see ·my power when I punish [the judgment I executed and the hand I laid on] them.

22.verse: From that time onward the ·people [house] of Israel will know that I am the LORD their God.

23.verse: The nations will know [the house of] Israel ·was taken away captive [went into exile] because they sinned and were unfaithful to me. So I ·turned away [hid my face] from them and handed them over to their enemies until all of them died ·in war [by the sword].

25.verse: “So this is what the Lord GOD says: Now I will ·bring the people of Jacob back from captivity [restore the fortunes of Jacob], and I will have ·mercy [compassion] on the whole ·nation [house] of Israel. I will ·not let them dishonor me [be zealous/jealous for my holy name].

26.verse: The people will forget their shame and ·how they rejected [their unfaithfulness to] me when they live again in safety on their own land with no one to make them afraid.

27.verse: I will bring the people back from ·other lands [the nations/peoples] and gather them from the lands of their enemies. So I will use my people to ·show many nations that I am holy [display my holiness in the eyes of many nations.].

28.verse: Then my people will know that I am the LORD their God, because I sent them into ·captivity [exile] among the nations, but then I ·brought them back [gathered them] to their own land, leaving no one behind.

1.verse: The New Temple - It was the twenty-fifth year [since King Jehoiachin’s exile (1:2)], at the beginning of the year, on the tenth day of the month [April 19, 573 BC]. It was in the fourteenth year after ·Jerusalem was captured [the city was struck down]. On that same day ·I felt the power of the LORD [the hand of the LORD was upon me], and he brought me to Jerusalem.

2.verse: In the visions of God he brought me to the land of Israel and put me down on a very high mountain. On the south of the mountain there were some buildings that looked like a city.

3.verse: He took me closer to the buildings, and ·I saw [look; behold] a man ·who looked as if he were made of [whose appearance was like] bronze, standing in the gateway. He had a cord made of linen and a stick in his hand, both for measuring.

4.verse: The man said to me, “·Human [Son of man; 2:1], look with your eyes and hear with your ears. ·Pay attention to [Set your heart upon] all that I will show you, because that’s why you have been brought here. Tell the ·people [house] of Israel all that you see.”

5.verse: The East Gateway - ·I saw [And look/behold] a wall that surrounded the ·Temple area [house]. The measuring ·stick [rod] in the man’s hand was ·ten and one-half feet long [six long cubits, each being a cubit and a handbreadth; a regular cubit was eighteen inches long; this long cubit was about twenty-one inches long]. So the man measured the wall, which was ·ten and one-half feet [six long cubits] thick and ·ten and one-half feet [one rod/stick] high.

6.verse: Then the man went to the east gateway. He went up its steps and measured the opening of the gateway. It was ·ten and one-half feet [one rod/stick; v. 5] deep.

7.verse: The ·rooms for the guards [alcoves] were ·ten and one-half feet [one rod/stick] long and ·ten and one-half feet [one rod/stick] wide. ·The walls that came out between the guards’ rooms [Between the alcoves] were ·about nine feet [five cubits; v. 5] thick. The ·opening [threshold] of the gateway next to the ·porch [portico] that faced the Temple was ·ten and one-half feet [one rod/stick] deep.

8.verse: Then the man measured the porch of the gateway.

9.verse: It was ·about fourteen feet [eight cubits] deep, and its ·side walls [or jambs] were ·three and one-half feet [two cubits] thick. The ·porch [portico] of the gateway faced the Temple.

10.verse: On each side of the east gateway were three ·rooms [alcoves], which ·measured the same on each side [had the same measurement]. The ·walls between each room [dividing walls; or jambs] ·were the same thickness [or had the same measurement].

11.verse: The man measured the width of the entrance to the gateway, which was ·seventeen and one-half feet [ten cubits; v. 5] wide. The ·width [or length] of the gate was ·about twenty-three feet [thirteen cubits].

12.verse: And there was a low ·wall [barrier] ·about twenty-one inches [one cubit] high in front of each ·room [alcove]. The ·rooms [alcoves] were ·ten and one-half feet [six cubits] on each side.

13.verse: The man measured the gateway from the roof of one ·room [alcove] to the roof of the opposite one. It was ·about forty-four feet [twenty-five cubits] from one door to the opposite door.

14.verse: The man also measured the ·porch [or jambs], which was ·about thirty-five feet [twenty cubits] wide. The courtyard was around the ·porch [or jamb; the meaning of this verse is uncertain].

15.verse: From the front of the ·outer side of the [entrance] gateway to the front of the porch of the ·inner side of the [inner] gateway was ·eighty-seven and one-half feet [fifty cubits].

16.verse: The ·rooms [alcoves] and porch had small windows on both sides. The windows were narrower on the side facing the gateway. Carvings of palm trees were on each side wall of the rooms.

17.verse: The Outer Courtyard - Then the man brought me into the outer courtyard ·where I saw [and look/behold] rooms and a pavement of stones all around the court. Thirty rooms ·were along the edge of [faced] the paved walkway.

19.verse: Then the man measured from the ·outer wall [front of the lower gate] to the ·inner wall [exterior face of the inner court]. The outer court between these two walls was ·one hundred seventy-five feet [one hundred cubits] on the east and on the north.

21.verse: Its three ·rooms [alcoves] on each side, its ·inner walls [or jambs], and its ·porch [portico] measured the same as the first gateway. It was ·eighty-seven and one-half feet [fifty cubits] long and ·forty-four feet [twenty-five cubits] wide.
