23.verse: The inner courtyard had a gateway across from the northern gateway like the one on the east. The man measured it and found it was ·one hundred seventy-five feet [one hundred cubits] from inner gateway to outer gateway.

24.verse: The South Gateway - Then the man led me south ·where I saw [and look/behold] a gateway facing south. He measured its ·inner walls [or jambs] and its ·porch [portico], and they measured the same as the other gateways.

25.verse: The gateway and its porch had windows all around like the other gateways. It was ·eighty-seven and one-half feet [fifty cubits] long and ·forty-four feet [twenty-five cubits] wide.

26.verse: Seven steps went up to this gateway. Its porch was at the inner end, and it had carvings of palm trees on its inner walls.

27.verse: The inner courtyard had a gateway on its south side. The man measured from gate to gate on the south side, which was ·one hundred seventy-five feet [one hundred cubits].

28.verse: The Inner Courtyard - Then the man brought me through the south gateway into the inner courtyard. The inner south gateway measured the same as the gateways in the outer wall.

29.verse: The inner south gateway’s ·rooms [alcoves], ·inner walls [or jambs], and ·porch [portico] measured the same as the gateways in the outer wall. There were windows all around the gateway and its porch. The gateway was ·eighty-seven and one-half feet [fifty cubits] long and ·forty-four feet [twenty-five cubits] wide.

30.verse: Each porch of each inner gateway was ·about forty-four feet [twenty-five cubits] long and ·about nine feet [five cubits] wide.

31.verse: The inner south gateway’s ·porch [portico] faced the outer courtyard. Carvings of palm trees were on its ·side walls [or jambs], and its stairway had eight steps.

32.verse: The man brought me into the inner courtyard on the east side. He measured the inner east gateway, and it was the same as the other gateways.

33.verse: The inner east gateway’s ·rooms [alcoves], ·inside walls [or jambs], and ·porch [portico] measured the same as the other gateways. Windows were all around the gateway and its ·porch [portico]. The inner east gateway was ·eighty-seven and one-half feet [fifty cubits] long and ·forty-four feet [twenty-five cubits] wide.

34.verse: Its porch faced the outer courtyard. Carvings of palm trees were on its ·inner walls [or jambs] on each side, and its stairway had eight steps.

35.verse: Then the man brought me to the inner north gateway. He measured it, and it was the same as the other gateways.

36.verse: Its ·rooms [alcoves], ·inside walls [or jambs], and ·porch [portico] measured the same as the other gateways. There were windows all around the gateway, which was ·eighty-seven and one-half feet [fifty cubits] long and ·forty-four feet [twenty-five cubits] wide.

37.verse: Its ·porch [portico] faced the outer courtyard. Carvings of palm trees were on its inner walls on each side, and its stairway had eight steps.

38.verse: Rooms for Preparing Sacrifices - There was a room with a door that opened onto the ·porch [portico] of the inner north gateway. ·In this room the priests washed animals for the burnt offerings […where the burnt offering was washed; Lev. 1:1–17].

39.verse: There were two tables on each side of the ·porch [portico], on which animals for burnt offerings, ·sin [or purification] offerings [Lev. 4:3], and ·penalty [guilt; reparation] offerings [Lev. 5:14—6:7] were killed.

40.verse: Outside, by each side wall of the ·porch [portico], at the entrance to the north gateway, were two more tables.

41.verse: So there were four tables inside the gateway, and four tables outside. In all there were eight tables on which ·the priests killed animals for sacrifices [to slaughter].

42.verse: There were four tables made of cut stone for the burnt offering [Lev. 1:1–17]. These tables were ·about three feet [a cubit and a half] long, ·three feet [a cubit and a half] wide, and ·about two feet [a cubit] high. On these tables the priests put their tools which they used to kill animals for burnt offerings and the other sacrifices.

43.verse: Double shelves ·three inches [one handbreadth] wide were put up on all the walls. The flesh for the offering was put on the tables.

44.verse: The Priests’ Rooms - There were two rooms in the inner courtyard. One was beside the north gateway and faced south. The other room was beside the south gateway and faced north.

45.verse: The man said to me, “The room which faces south is for the priests who ·serve in [or guard; or have charge of] the Temple area,

46.verse: while the room that faces north is for the priests who ·serve at [or guard; or have charge of] the altar. This second group of priests are descendants of Zadok, the only descendants of Levi who can come near the LORD to ·serve [minister to] him.”

47.verse: The man measured the inner courtyard. It was a square—·one hundred seventy-five feet [one hundred cubits] long and ·one hundred seventy-five feet [one hundred cubits] wide. The altar was in front of the Temple.

48.verse: The Temple Porch - The man brought me to the ·porch [portico] of the Temple and measured each ·side wall [or jamb] of the ·porch [portico]. Each was ·about nine feet [five cubits] thick. The doorway was ·twenty-four and one-half feet [fourteen cubits] wide. The side walls of the doorway were each ·about five feet [three cubits] wide.

49.verse: The ·porch [portico] was ·thirty-five feet [twenty cubits] long and ·twenty-one feet [twelve cubits] wide, with ten steps leading up to it. Pillars were by the ·side walls [or jambs], one on each side of the entrance.

1.verse: The Holy Place of the Temple - The man brought me to the ·Holy Place [outer sanctuary; main hall] and measured its ·side walls [or jambs], which were each ·ten and one-half feet [six cubits] thick.

2.verse: The entrance was ·seventeen and one-half feet [ten cubits] wide. The walls alongside the entrance were each ·about nine feet wide [five cubits]. The man measured the ·Holy Place [outer sanctuary; main hall], which was ·seventy feet [forty cubits] long and ·thirty-five feet [twenty cubits] wide.

3.verse: Then the man went ·inside [into the inner sanctuary] and measured the ·side walls [or jambs] of the next doorway. Each was ·three and one-half feet [two cubits] thick. The doorway was ·ten and one-half feet [six cubits] wide, and the walls next to it were each more than ·twelve [seven cubits] feet thick.

4.verse: Then the man measured the room ·at the end of [or adjacent to] the ·Holy Place [outer sanctuary; main hall]. It was ·thirty-five feet [twenty cubits] long and ·thirty-five feet [twenty cubits] long wide. The man said to me, “This is the Most Holy Place.”

5.verse: Then the man measured the wall of the ·Temple [house], which was ·ten and one-half feet [six cubits] thick. There were side rooms ·seven feet [four cubits] wide all around the Temple.

6.verse: The side rooms were on three different stories, each above the other, with thirty rooms on each story. All around the Temple walls there were ledges for the side rooms. The upper rooms rested on the ledges but were not attached to the Temple walls.

7.verse: The side rooms around the Temple were wider on each higher story, so rooms were wider on the top story. ·A stairway went [or So one went] up from the lowest story to the highest through the middle story.

8.verse: I also saw that the Temple had a raised ·base [platform] all around. Its edge was the foundation for the side rooms, and it was ·ten and one-half feet thick [a full rod/stick of six cubits].

9.verse: The outer wall of the side rooms was ·about nine feet [five cubits] thick. There was an open area between the side rooms of the Temple

10.verse: and some other rooms. It was ·thirty-five feet [twenty cubits] wide and went all around the Temple.

11.verse: The side rooms had doors which led to the open area around the outside of the Temple. One door faced north, and the other faced south. The open area was ·about nine feet [five cubits] wide all around.

12.verse: The building facing the ·private area [temple courtyard] at the west side was ·one hundred twenty-two and one-half feet [seventy cubits] wide. The wall around the building was ·about nine feet [five cubits] thick and ·one hundred fifty-seven and one-half feet [ninety cubits] long.

13.verse: Then the man measured the Temple. It was ·one hundred seventy-five feet [one hundred cubits] long. The ·private area [temple courtyard], including the building and its walls, was in all ·one hundred seventy-five feet [one hundred cubits] long.

14.verse: Also the front of the Temple and the ·private area [courtyard] on its east side were ·one hundred seventy-five feet [one hundred cubits] wide.

15.verse: The man measured the length of the building facing the ·private area [courtyard] ·on the west side [or at the rear], and it was ·one hundred seventy-five feet [one hundred cubits] ·from one wall to the other [or with its galleries on each side]. The ·Holy Place, the Most Holy Place [or interior of the outer sanctuary/main hall], and the outer porch

16.verse: had wood panels on the walls. By the ·doorway [thresholds], the Temple had wood panels on the walls. The wood covered all the walls from the floor up to the windows,

17.verse: up to the part of the wall above the entrance. All the walls inside the ·Most Holy Place and the Holy Place [inner and outer sanctuary], and on the outside, in the ·porch [portico],

18.verse: had carvings of ·creatures with wings [cherubim] and palm trees. A palm tree was between each ·carved creature [cherub], and every ·creature [cherub] had two faces.

19.verse: One was a human face looking toward the palm tree on one side. The other was a lion’s face looking toward the palm tree on the other side. They were carved all around the Temple walls.

20.verse: From the floor to above the entrance, palm trees and ·creatures with wings [cherubim] were carved. The walls of the Holy Place

21.verse: had square doorposts. In front of the ·Most Holy Place [sanctuary] was something that looked like

22.verse: an altar of wood. It was more than ·five feet [three cubits] high and ·three feet [two cubits] wide. Its corners, base, and sides were wood. The man said to me, “This is the table that is ·in the presence of [before] the LORD.”

23.verse: Both the ·Holy Place [main hall; outer sanctuary] and the ·Most Holy Place [inner sanctuary] had double doors.

24.verse: Each of the doors had two ·pieces [leaves] that would swing open. Two for one and two for the other.

25.verse: Carved on the doors of the ·Holy Place [main hall; outer sanctuary] were palm trees and ·creatures with wings [cherubim], like those carved on the walls. And there was a wood ·roof [canopy] over the front Temple ·porch [portico].

26.verse: There were narrow windows and palm trees on both side walls of the ·porch [portico]. The side rooms of the Temple were also covered by a ·roof [canopy] over the stairway.

1.verse: The Priests’ Rooms - Then the man led me north out into the outer courtyard and to the rooms across from the ·private area [temple courtyard] and the building.

2.verse: These rooms on the north side were ·one hundred seventy-five feet [one hundred cubits] long and ·eighty-seven and one-half feet [fifty cubits] wide.

3.verse: There was ·thirty-five feet [twenty cubits] of the inner courtyard between them and the Temple. On the other side, they faced the stone pavement of the outer courtyard. The rooms were built in three stories like steps ·and had balconies [with gallery facing gallery].

4.verse: There was a ·path [passageway; walkway] in front of the rooms on the inner side, which was ·seventeen and one-half feet [ten cubits] wide and ·one hundred seventy-five feet [one hundred cubits] long. The entrances to the rooms were on the north.

5.verse: The ·top [upper] rooms were narrower, because the ·balconies [galleries] took more space from them. The rooms on the first and second stories of the building were wider.

6.verse: The rooms were on three stories. They did not have pillars like the pillars of the courtyards. So the ·top [upper] rooms were farther back than those on the first and second stories.

7.verse: There was a wall outside parallel to the rooms and to the outer courtyard. It ran in front of the rooms for ·eighty-seven and one-half feet [fifty cubits].

8.verse: The row of rooms along the outer courtyard was ·eighty-seven and one-half feet [fifty cubits] long, and the rooms that faced the ·Temple [main hall; sanctuary] were ·about one hundred seventy-five feet [one hundred cubits] long.

9.verse: The lower rooms had an entrance on the east side so a person could enter them from the outer courtyard,

10.verse: at the start of the wall beside the courtyard [some interpret this phrase as beginning the next sentence]. There were rooms on the south side, which were across from the ·private area [Temple courtyard] and the building.

11.verse: These rooms had a path in front of them. They were like the rooms on the north with the same length and width and the same exits, measurements and doors.

12.verse: The doors of the south rooms were like the doors of the north rooms. There was an entrance at the ·open end [or beginning] of a path beside the wall, so a person could enter at the east end.

13.verse: The man said to me, “The north and south rooms across from the ·private area [courtyard] are holy rooms. There the priests who ·go near [approach] the LORD will eat the most holy offerings. There they will put the most holy offerings: the ·grain [gift; tribute] offerings [Lev. 2:1], ·sin [or purification] offerings [Lev. 4:3], and the ·penalty [guilt; reparation] offerings [Lev. 5:14–6:7], because the place is holy.

14.verse: The priests who enter the Holy Place must leave ·their serving clothes [garments in which they minister] there before they go into the outer courtyard, because these ·clothes [garments] are holy. After they put on other ·clothes [garments], they may go to the part of the Temple area which is for the people.”

15.verse: Outside the Temple Area - When the man finished measuring inside the Temple area, he brought me out through the east gateway. He measured the area all around.

16.verse: The man measured the east side with the measuring stick; it was ·eight hundred seventy-five feet [five hundred cubits] by the measuring ·stick [rod].

17.verse: He measured the north side; it was ·eight hundred seventy-five feet [five hundred cubits] by the measuring stick.

18.verse: He measured the south side; it was ·eight hundred seventy-five feet [five hundred cubits] by the measuring stick.

19.verse: He went around to the west side; it measured ·eight hundred seventy-five feet [five hundred cubits] by the measuring stick.

20.verse: So he measured the Temple area on all four sides. The Temple area had a wall all around it that was ·eight hundred seventy-five feet long [five hundred cubits] and ·eight hundred seventy-five feet [five hundred cubits] wide. It separated what was holy from ·that which was not holy [the common/profane; ritually].

1.verse: The Lord Among His People - Then the man led me to the outer east gateway,

2.verse: and [look; behold] I saw the glory of the God of Israel [his manifest presence] coming from the east. It sounded like the roar of rushing water, and ·its brightness made the earth shine [the earth radiated/shone with his glory].

3.verse: The vision I saw was like the vision I had seen when the LORD came to destroy the city [ch. 9] and also like the vision I had seen by the Kebar ·River [Canal; 1:1]. I ·bowed [fell] facedown on the ground.

4.verse: The glory of the LORD came into the ·Temple area [house] through the east gateway.

5.verse: Then ·the Spirit [or the spirit; or a wind; 2:2; 3:12] picked me up and brought me into the inner courtyard. ·There I saw [And look/behold] the LORD’s glory filling the ·Temple [house].

6.verse: As the man stood at my side, I heard someone speaking to me from inside the ·Temple [house].

7.verse: The voice said to me, “·Human [Son of man; 2:1], this is my throne and the place ·where my feet rest [for the soles of my feet]. I will live here among the ·Israelites [sons/children or Israel] forever. The ·people [house] of Israel will not make my holy name ·unclean [defiled; ritually] again. Neither the people nor their kings will ·make it unclean [defile my holy name; ritually] with their ·sexual sins [prostitution] or with the ·dead bodies [corpses in their death; or funeral monuments/pillars] of their kings.

8.verse: The kings ·made my name unclean [defiled my holy name; ritually] by putting their ·doorway [threshold] next to my ·doorway [threshold], and their doorpost next to my doorpost so only a wall separated me from them [kings erected monuments to themselves around the temple]. When they did their ·acts that I hate [detestable/abominable acts], they ·made my holy name unclean [defiled my holy name; ritually], and so I ·destroyed [consumed] them in my anger.

9.verse: Now let them stop their ·sexual sins [prostitution] and take the ·dead bodies [or funeral pillars; v. 7] of their kings far away from me. Then I will live among them forever.

10.verse: “·Human [Son of man; 2:1], tell the ·people [house] of Israel about the ·Temple [house] so they will be ashamed of their ·sins [iniquities]. Let them ·think about the plan of the Temple [study its plan; or consider its perfection].

11.verse: If they are ashamed of all they have done, let them know the design of the ·Temple [house] and how it is built. Show them its exits and entrances, all its designs, and also all its ·rules [statutes; ordinances; requirements] and ·teachings [laws; instructions]. Write it down ·as they watch [in their sight] so they will obey all its ·teachings [laws; instructions] and its ·rules [statutes; ordinances; requirements].

12.verse: This is the ·teaching about [law of] the ·Temple [house]: All the area around the top of the mountain is most holy. This is the ·teaching about [law/instruction of] the ·Temple [house].

13.verse: The Altar - “These are the measurements of the altar, ·using the measuring stick [in long cubits, each being a cubit and a handbreadth; 40:5]. The altar’s ·gutter [base] is ·twenty-one inches [one cubit] high and ·twenty-one inches [one cubit] wide, and its rim is ·about nine inches [one span] around its edge. And the altar is this tall:

14.verse: From the base on the ground up to the lower ledge, it measures ·three and one-half feet [two cubits]. It is ·twenty-one inches [one cubit] wide. It measures ·seven feet [four cubits] from the smaller ledge to the larger ledge and is ·twenty-one inches [one cubit] wide.

15.verse: The ·place where the sacrifice is burned on the altar [altar hearth] is ·seven feet [four cubits] high, with its four ·corners shaped like horns and reaching up above it [horns projecting upward; Ex. 27:2].

16.verse: It is square, ·twenty-one feet [twelve cubits] long and ·twenty-one feet [twelve cubits] wide.

17.verse: The upper ledge is also square, ·twenty-four and one-half feet [fourteen cubits] long and ·twenty-four and one-half feet [fourteen cubits] wide. The rim around the altar is ·ten and one-half inches [one-half cubit] wide, and its ·gutter [base] is ·twenty-one inches [one cubit] wide all around. Its steps ·are on the east side [face east].”

18.verse: Then the man said to me, “·Human [Son of man; 2:1], this is what the Lord GOD says: These are the ·rules [statutes; ordinances; requirements] for the altar. ·When [On the day] it is built, use these rules to offer burnt offerings [Lev. 1:1–17] and to sprinkle blood on it [Lev. 1:5].

19.verse: You must give a young bull as a ·sin [or purification] offering [Lev. 4:3] to the priests, the Levites who are from the ·family [seed; offspring] of Zadok and who come near me to ·serve [minister to] me, says the Lord GOD.

20.verse: Take some of the bull’s blood and put it on the four ·corners [horns; Ex. 27:2] of the altar, on the four corners of the ledge, and all around the rim. This is how you will ·make the altar pure [cleanse/purify the altar] and ·ready for God’s service [make atonement for it].

21.verse: Then take the bull for the ·sin [or purification] offering [Lev. 4:3] and burn it in the ·proper [appointed; designated] place ·in the Temple area [of the house], outside the ·Temple building [sanctuary].

22.verse: “On the second day offer a male goat ·that has nothing wrong with it [without blemish/defect] for a sin offering. The priests will ·make the altar pure and ready for God’s service [cleanse/purify the altar] as they did with the young bull.

23.verse: When you finish ·making the altar pure and ready [purifying it], offer a young bull and a male sheep from the flock, ·which have nothing wrong with them [without blemish/defect].

24.verse: You must offer them ·in the presence of [before] the LORD, and the priests are to throw salt on them and offer them as a burnt offering [Lev. 1:1–17] to the LORD.

25.verse: “You must prepare a goat every day for seven days as a sin offering. Also, the priests must prepare a young bull and ·male sheep [ram] from the flock, ·which have nothing wrong with them [without blemish/defect].

26.verse: For seven days the priests are to make ·the altar pure and ready for God’s service [atonement for the altar and cleanse it]. Then they will ·give the altar to God [consecrate/dedicate it; fill its hands].

27.verse: ·After these seven days [When these days are completed], on the eighth day, the priests must offer your burnt offerings [Lev. 1:1–17] and your ·fellowship [or peace; well-being] offerings [Lev. 3:1] on the altar. Then I will accept you, says the Lord GOD.”

1.verse: The Outer East Gate - Then the man brought me back to the outer east gateway of the ·Temple area [sanctuary], but the gate was shut.

2.verse: The LORD said to me, “This gate will stay shut; it will not be opened. No one may enter through it, because the LORD God of Israel has entered through it. So it must stay shut.

3.verse: Only the ·ruler [prince] himself may sit in the gateway to eat ·a meal [bread; probably his portion of the fellowship offering; Lev. 7:15; Deut. 12:7] ·in the presence of [before] the LORD. He must enter through the porch of the gateway and go out the same way.”

4.verse: Then the man brought me through the outer north gate to the front of the ·Temple [house]. As I looked, ·I saw [look; behold] the glory of the LORD [his manifest presence] filling the Temple of the LORD, and I ·bowed [fell] facedown on the ground.

5.verse: The LORD said to me, “·Human [Son of man; 2:1], pay attention. Use your eyes to see, and your ears to hear. See and hear everything I tell you about all the ·rules [statutes; ordinances; requirements] and ·teachings [laws; instructions] of the ·Temple [house] of the LORD. Pay attention to the entrance to the Temple and to all the exits from the ·Temple area [sanctuary].

6.verse: Then speak to ·those who refuse to obey [the rebellious]. Say to the ·people [house] of Israel, ‘This is what the Lord GOD says: ·Stop doing all [Enough of] your ·acts that I hate [detestable/abominable acts], [house of] Israel!

7.verse: You brought foreigners into my ·Holy Place [sanctuary] who were not circumcised in the flesh and ·had not given themselves to serving me [uncircumcised in the heart; Jer. 9:26; Acts 7:51]. You ·dishonored [defiled; profaned; ritually] my ·Temple [house] when you offered me food, fat, and blood. You broke my ·agreement [covenant; treaty] by all ·the things you did that I hate [your detestable/abominable acts].

8.verse: You did not take ·care [charge] of my holy things yourselves but put ·foreigners [or others] ·in charge of [to take care of] my ·Temple [sanctuary].

9.verse: This is what the Lord GOD says: Foreigners who ·do not give themselves to serving me [are uncircumcised in heart] and who are uncircumcised in flesh may not enter my ·Temple [sanctuary]. Not even a foreigner living among the ·people [sons/children] of Israel may enter.

10.verse: “‘But the Levites who ·stopped obeying [went far from] me when Israel ·left me [went astray] and who followed their idols must ·be punished [be responsible; bear the penalty] for their sin.

11.verse: These Levites are to be ·servants in [ministers of] my ·Holy Place [sanctuary]. They may guard the gates of the ·Temple [house] and serve in the ·Temple area [house]. They may ·kill the animals for [slaughter] the burnt offering [Lev. 1:1–17] and the sacrifices for the people. They may stand before the people to ·serve [minister to] them.

12.verse: But these Levites ·helped the people worship [ministered to them before] their idols and caused the ·people [house] of Israel to ·fall [stumble], so I ·make this promise [swear with uplifted hand]: They will ·be punished [be responsible; bear the penalty] for their sin, says the Lord GOD.

13.verse: They will not come near me to serve as priests, nor will they come near any of my holy things or the most holy offerings. But they will ·be made ashamed of [bear the shame for] ·the things they did that I hate [their detestable/abominable actions].

14.verse: Yet I will ·put them in charge of taking care [appoint them to guard/keep charge] of the ·Temple area [house], all the work that must be done in it.

15.verse: “‘But the priests who are Levites and descendants of Zadok took care of my ·Holy Place [sanctuary] when [the sons/children of] Israel ·left me [went astray], so they may come near to serve me. They may stand in my presence to offer me the fat and blood [of sacrificial animals], says the Lord GOD.

16.verse: They ·are the only ones who may [will] enter my ·Holy Place [sanctuary]. ·Only they [They] may come near my table to ·serve [minister to] me and ·take care of the things I gave them to do [keep my charge; or serve me as guards].

17.verse: “‘When they enter the gates of the inner courtyard, they must wear linen robes. They must not wear wool to ·serve [minister] at the gates of the inner courtyard or in the ·Temple [house].

18.verse: They will wear linen turbans on their heads and linen underclothes [Lev. 6:10]. They will not ·wear [bind/gird themselves with] anything that makes them perspire.

19.verse: When they go out into the outer courtyard to the people, they must take off their serving ·clothes [garments] before they go. They must leave these clothes in the ·holy rooms [sacred chambers] and put on other ·clothes [garments]. Then they will not ·let their holy clothes hurt [or transmit holiness with their garments to] the people.

20.verse: “‘They must not shave their heads or let their hair grow long but must keep the hair of their heads trimmed [Lev. 21:5].

21.verse: None of the priests may drink wine when they enter the inner courtyard [Lev. 10:9].

22.verse: The priests must not marry widows or divorced women. They may marry only virgins from the ·people [offspring/seed of the house] of Israel or widows of priests [Lev. 21:7–8].

23.verse: They must teach my people the difference between what is holy and what is ·not holy [common; profane; ritually]. They must help my people know what is unclean [ritually] and what is clean.

24.verse: “‘In ·court [a dispute/controversy] they will act as judges. When they judge, they will follow my ·teachings [judgments]. They must obey my ·laws [teachings; instructions] and my ·rules [statutes; ordinances; requirements] at all my ·special feasts [appointed festivals] and keep my Sabbaths holy.

25.verse: “‘They must not go near a dead person, ·making themselves unclean [defiling themselves; ritually]. But they are allowed to ·make themselves unclean [defile themselves; ritually] if the dead person is their father, mother, son, daughter, brother, or a sister who has not married.

26.verse: After a priest has been ·made clean again [cleansed; ritually], he must wait seven days.

27.verse: Then he may go into the inner courtyard to serve in the ·Temple [sanctuary], but he must offer a sin offering for himself, says the Lord GOD [Lev. 21:1–4].

28.verse: “‘·These are the rules about the priests and their property [This will be their inheritance]: ·They will have me instead of property [I am their inheritance]. You will not give them any ·land to own [possessions] in Israel; I am ·what they will own [their possession].

29.verse: They will eat the ·grain [gift; tribute] offerings [Lev. 2:1], ·sin [or purification] offerings [Lev. 4:3], and ·penalty [guilt; reparation] offerings [Lev. 5:14—6:7]. ·Everything Israel gives to me [Every devoted thing in Israel] will be theirs.

30.verse: The ·best [first] fruits of all the first harvests and all the special gifts offered to me will belong to the priests. You will also give to the priests the first part of your ·grain that you grind [dough] ·and so bring a blessing [that a blessing may rest] on your family.

31.verse: The priests must not eat any bird or animal that died a natural death or one that has been torn by wild animals.

1.verse: The Land Is Divided - “‘When you divide the land for the Israelite tribes by throwing lots, you must give a part of the land to belong to the LORD. It will be ·about seven miles [twenty-five thousand cubits] long and ·about six miles [twenty thousand cubits] wide; all of this land will be holy.

2.verse: From this land, an area ·eight hundred seventy-five feet [five hundred cubits] square will be for the ·Temple [sanctuary]. There will be an open space around the Temple that is ·eighty-seven and one-half feet [fifty cubits] wide.

3.verse: In the holy area you will measure a part ·about seven miles [twenty-five thousand cubits] long and ·three miles wide [ten thousand cubits], and in it will be the sanctuary, the Most Holy Place.

4.verse: This ·holy part [sacred portion] of the land will be for the priests who ·serve [minister] in the ·Temple [sanctuary], who come near to the LORD to ·serve [minister to] him. It will be a place for the priests’ houses and ·for the Temple [a holy place for the sanctuary].

5.verse: Another area ·about seven miles [twenty-five thousand cubits] long and ·three miles wide [ten thousand cubits] will be for the Levites, who ·serve [minister] in the Temple area. It will belong to them so they will have cities in which to live.

6.verse: “‘You must give the city an area that is ·about one and one-half miles [five thousand cubits] wide and ·about seven miles [twenty-five thousand cubits] long, along the side of the holy area. It will belong to all the ·people [house] of Israel.

7.verse: “‘The ·ruler [prince] will have land on both sides of the holy ·area [allotment; contribution] and the city. On the west of the holy area, his land will reach to the eastern border [apparently the Mediterranean Sea]. On the east of the holy area, his land will reach to the eastern border [of the country]. It will be as long as the land given to each tribe.

8.verse: Only this land will be the ruler’s ·property [possession] in Israel. So my rulers will not ·be cruel to [oppress] my people anymore [such a large portion would keep the king from wanting to seize land, as Ahab had done (1 Kin. 21); see v. 9], but they will let each tribe in the ·nation [house] of Israel have its share of the land.

9.verse: “‘This is what the Lord GOD says: ·You have gone far enough [Enough!], you ·rulers [princes] of Israel! Stop ·being cruel and hurting people [your violence and oppression], and do what is right and ·fair [just]. Stop ·forcing my people out of their homes [evicting my people], says the Lord GOD.

10.verse: You must have ·honest [just] scales, an ·honest [just] ·dry measurement [ephah] and an ·honest [just] ·liquid measurement [bath].

11.verse: The dry measure [ephah] and the liquid measure [bath] will be the same: The ·liquid measure [bath] will always be a tenth of a homer [ the Hebrew means “donkey-load,” and was about five bushels of dry measure and 55 gallons of liquid measure], and the dry measure [ephah] will always be a tenth of a homer. The ·measurement they follow [standard measure] will be the homer.

12.verse: The shekel [coin weighing about two-fifths of an ounce] will be worth twenty gerahs, and a mina will be worth ·sixty shekels [twenty shekels and twenty-five shekels and fifteen shekels].

13.verse: Offerings and Holy Days - “‘This is the ·gift [offering] you should offer: a sixth of an ephah [v. 11] from every homer [v. 11] of wheat, and a sixth of an ephah from every homer of barley.

14.verse: The amount of oil you are to offer is a tenth of a bath [v. 11] from each cor. (Ten baths make a homer and also make a cor.)

15.verse: You should give one sheep from each flock of two hundred from the watering places of Israel. All these are to be offered for the ·grain [gift; tribute] offerings [Lev. 2:1], burnt offerings [Lev. 1:1–17], and ·fellowship [or peace; well-being] offerings [Lev. 3:1] to ·remove the sins of [make atonement for] the people, says the Lord GOD.

16.verse: All people in the land will give this special offering to the ·ruler [prince] of Israel.

17.verse: It will be the ·ruler’s [prince’s] responsibility to supply the burnt offerings [Lev. 1:1–17], ·grain [gift; tribute] offerings [Lev. 2:1], and drink offerings. These offerings will be given at the ·feasts [appointed festivals], at the New Moons, on the Sabbaths, and at all the other feasts of [the house of] Israel. He will supply the ·sin [or purification] offerings [Lev. 4:3], ·grain [gift; tribute] offerings, and ·fellowship [or peace; well-being] offerings [Lev. 3:1] to pay for the sins of [the house of] Israel.

18.verse: “‘This is what the Lord GOD says: On the first day of the first month take a young bull ·that has nothing wrong with it [without blemish/defect]. Use it to ·make the Temple pure and ready for God’s service [purify the sanctuary].

19.verse: The priest will take some of the blood from this ·sin [or purification] offering [Lev. 4:3] and put it on the doorposts of the ·Temple [house], on the four corners of the ledge of the altar, and on the posts of the gate to the inner courtyard.

20.verse: You will do the same thing on the seventh day of the month for anyone who has sinned ·by accident [unintentionally] or ·without knowing it [through ignorance]. This is how you make ·the Temple pure and ready for God’s service [atonement for the house].

21.verse: Passover Feast Offerings - “‘On the fourteenth day of the first month you will celebrate the Feast of Passover [Ex. 12:1–20; Lev. 23:4–8; Num. 28:16–25; Deut. 16:1–5]. It will be a feast of seven days when you eat ·bread made without yeast [unleavened bread].

22.verse: On that day the ·ruler [prince] ·must offer [will provide] a bull for himself and for all the people of the land as a ·sin [or purification] offering [Lev. 4:3].

23.verse: During the seven days of the feast he ·must offer [will provide] seven bulls and seven ·male sheep [rams] ·that have nothing wrong with them [without blemish/defect]. They will be burnt offerings [Lev. 1:1–17] to the LORD, which the ruler will offer every day of the seven days of the feast. He must also offer a male goat every day as a ·sin [or purification] offering [Lev. 4:3].

24.verse: The ruler ·must give [will provide] as a ·grain [gift; tribute] offering [Lev. 2:1] ·one-half bushel [an ephah; v. 11] for each bull and ·one-half bushel [an ephah] for each sheep. He must give a ·gallon [hin] of olive oil for each half bushel.

25.verse: “‘Beginning on the fifteenth day of the seventh month, when you celebrate the ·Feast of Shelters [Feast/Festival; Lev. 23:33–44; Num. 28:12–40], the ruler will supply the same ·things [provisions] for seven days: the ·sin [or purification] offerings [Lev. 4:3], burnt offerings [Lev. 1:1–17], ·grain [gift; tribute] offerings [Lev. 2:1], and the olive oil.

1.verse: Rules for Worship - “‘This is what the Lord GOD says: The east gate of the inner courtyard will stay shut on the six working days, but it will be opened on the Sabbath day and on the day of the New Moon.

2.verse: The ·ruler [prince] will enter from outside through the ·porch [portico] of the gateway and stand by the gatepost, while the priests offer the ·ruler’s [prince’s] burnt offering [Lev. 1:1–17] and ·fellowship [or peace; well-being] offering [Lev. 3:1]. The ruler will ·worship [bow down] at the ·entrance [threshold] of the gateway, and then he will go out. But the gate will not be shut until evening.

3.verse: The people of the land will worship at the entrance of that gateway ·in the presence of [before] the LORD on the Sabbaths and New Moons.

4.verse: This is the burnt offering [Lev. 1:1–17] the ruler will offer to the LORD on the Sabbath day: six male lambs ·that have nothing wrong with them [without blemish/defect] and a ·male sheep [ram] ·that has nothing wrong with it [without blemish/defect].

5.verse: He must give a ·half-bushel [ephah; 45:11] ·grain [gift; tribute] offering with the male sheep, but he ·may [or will] give as much grain offering with the lambs as ·he pleases [or he is able; a gift of his hand]. He must also give a ·gallon [hin] of olive oil for each ·half bushel [ephah] of grain.

6.verse: On the day of the New Moon he must offer a young bull ·that has nothing wrong with it [without blemish/defect]. He must also offer six lambs and a male sheep ·that have nothing wrong with them [all without blemish/defect].

7.verse: The ruler must give a ·half-bushel [ephah] ·grain [gift; tribute] offering [Lev. 2:1] with the bull and ·one-half bushel [an ephah] with the ·male sheep [ram]. With the lambs, he ·may [or will] give as much grain ·as he pleases [or as he is able; a gift of his hand]. But he must give a ·gallon [hin] of olive oil for each half bushel of grain.

8.verse: When the ·ruler [prince] enters, he must go in through the ·porch [portico] of the gateway, and he must go out the same way.

9.verse: “‘When the people of the land come ·into the LORD’s presence [before the LORD] at the ·special feasts [appointed festivals], those who enter through the north gate to worship must go out through the south gate. Those who enter through the south gate must go out through the north gate. They must not return the same way they entered; everyone must go out ·the opposite way [straight ahead].

10.verse: The ·ruler [prince] will go in with the people when they go in and go out with them when they go out.

11.verse: “‘At the feasts and ·regular times of worship [appointed festivals] ·one-half bushel [an ephah] of grain must be offered with a young bull, and ·one-half bushel [an ephah] of grain must be offered with a ·male sheep [ram]. But with an offering of lambs, the ruler may give as much grain as ·he pleases [or he is able; a gift of his hand]. He should give a ·gallon [hin] of olive oil for each ·half bushel [ephah] of grain.

12.verse: The ·ruler [prince] may give an ·offering as a special gift to the LORD [freewill offering]; it may be a burnt offering [Lev. 1:1–17] or ·fellowship [or peace; well-being] offering [Lev. 3:1]. When he gives it to the LORD, the ·inner east gate [gate facing east] is to be opened for him. He must offer his burnt offering or his ·fellowship [or peace; well-being] offering [Lev. 3:1] as he does on the Sabbath day. Then he will go out, and the gate will be shut after he has left.

13.verse: “‘Every day you will give a year-old lamb ·that has nothing wrong with it [without blemish/defect] for a burnt offering [Lev. 1:1–17] to the LORD. Do it ·every morning [morning by morning].

14.verse: Also, you must offer a ·grain [gift; tribute] offering [Lev. 2:1] with the lamb ·every morning [morning by morning]. For this you will give ·three and one-third quarts [a sixth of an ephah] of grain and ·one and one-third quarts [a third of an ephah] of olive oil, to make the fine flour moist, as a ·grain [gift; tribute] offering [Lev. 2:1] to the LORD. This is a ·rule that must be kept from now on [perpetual statute; lasting ordinance].

15.verse: So you must always give the lamb, together with the ·grain [gift; tribute] offering [Lev. 2:1] and the olive oil, ·every morning [morning by morning] as a ·regular [perpetual] burnt offering [Lev. 1:1–17].

16.verse: Rules for the Ruler - “‘This is what the Lord GOD says: If the ·ruler [prince] gives a gift from his ·land [inheritance] to any of his sons, that land will belong to the son and then to the son’s children. It is their property ·passed down from their family [by inheritance].

17.verse: But if the ruler gives a gift from his ·land [inheritance] to any of his servants, that land will belong to the servant only until the year of freedom [the year of Jubilee; Lev. 25:8–15]. Then the land will go back to the ·ruler [prince]. ·Only the ruler’s sons may keep a gift of land from the ruler [His inheritance shall be only for his sons].

18.verse: The ·ruler [prince] must not take any of the people’s ·land [inheritance], forcing them out of their land. He must give his sons ·some of his own land [inheritance from his own property] so my people will not be scattered out of their own land.’”

19.verse: The Special Kitchens - The man led me through the entrance at the side of the gateway to the priests’ ·holy rooms [sacred chambers] that face north. ·There I saw [And look/behold] a place at the far west end.

20.verse: The man said to me, “This is where the priests will boil the ·meat of the penalty [penalty; or guilt; reparation] offering [Lev. 5:14—6:7] and ·sin [or purification] offering [Lev. 4:3] and bake the ·grain [gift; tribute] offering [Lev. 3:1]. Then they will not need to bring these holy offerings into the outer courtyard, ·because that would hurt [which would transmit holiness to] the people [the purity of God’s holiness would destroy sinful human beings; Lev. 16:2].”

21.verse: Then the man brought me out into the outer courtyard and led me to its four corners. [And look/behold] In each corner of the courtyard was a smaller courtyard.

22.verse: Small courtyards were in the four corners of the courtyard. Each small courtyard was the same size, ·seventy feet [forty cubits] long and ·fifty-two and one-half feet [thirty cubits] wide.

23.verse: A ·stone wall [row] was around each of the four small courtyards, and ·places for cooking [fireplaces; boiling places] were built in each of the ·stone walls [rows].

24.verse: The man said to me, “These are the kitchens where those who ·work [minister] in the Temple will boil the sacrifices offered by the people.”

1.verse: The River from the Temple - The man led me back to the door of the ·Temple [house], and ·I saw [look; behold] water coming out from under the ·doorway [threshold] and flowing east. (The Temple faced east.) The water flowed down from the south side wall of the Temple and then south of the altar.

2.verse: The man brought me out through the outer north gate and led me around outside to the outer east gate. ·I found [And look/behold] the water ·coming [trickling] out on the south side of the gate.

3.verse: The man went toward the east with a measuring line in his hand and measured ·about one-third of a mile [a thousand cubits]. Then he led me through water that came up to my ankles.

4.verse: The man measured ·about one-third of a mile [a thousand] again and led me through water that came up to my knees. Then he measured ·about one-third of a mile [a thousand] again and led me through water up to my waist.

5.verse: The man measured ·about one-third of a mile [a thousand] again, but it was now a river that I could not cross. The water had risen too high; it was deep enough for swimming; it was a river that no one could cross.

6.verse: The man asked me, “·Human [Son of man; 2:1], do you see this?” Then the man led me back to the bank of the river.

7.verse: As I went back, I saw many trees on both sides of the river.

8.verse: The man said to me, “This water will flow toward the eastern areas and go down into the ·Jordan Valley [Arabah]. When it enters the ·Dead Sea [Sea], it will ·become fresh [be healed; the Dead Sea has no fish or other living creatures due to its high mineral content].

9.verse: Everywhere the river goes, there will be many fish. Wherever this water goes the ·Dead Sea [Sea] will become fresh, and so where the river goes there will be ·many [swarms of] living things.

10.verse: Fishermen will stand by ·the Dead Sea [it]. From En Gedi [midway along the western side of the Dead Sea] all the way to En Eglaim [an unknown location, perhaps on the east bank of the Dead Sea] there will be places to spread fishing nets. There will be many kinds of fish there, as many as in the ·Mediterranean [Great] Sea.

11.verse: But its swamps and marshes will not become fresh; they will ·be left for salt [or remain salty].

12.verse: All kinds of fruit trees will grow on both banks of the river. Their leaves will not ·dry and die [wither] and ·there will always be fruit on them [their fruit will not fail]. The trees will bear fruit every month, because the water for them comes from the ·Temple [sanctuary]. The fruit from the trees will be used for food, and their leaves for ·medicine [healing].”

13.verse: Borders of the Land - This is what the Lord GOD says: “These are the borders of the land to be divided for an inheritance among the twelve tribes of Israel. Joseph will have two parts of land [the tribes of Ephraim and Manasseh, Joseph’s two sons adopted by Jacob (Gen. 48:17–20)].

14.verse: You will divide the land equally. I ·promised [vowed; swore with uplifted hand] to give it to your ·ancestors [fathers], so this land will ·belong to you as family property [become your inheritance].

15.verse: “This will be the ·border line [boundary] of the land: “On the north side it will start at the ·Mediterranean [Great] Sea. It will go through Hethlon, toward ·Lebo Hamath [or Lebo of Hamath; often identified as the northern limit of Israel; Num. 13:21; Josh. 13:5; 1 Kin. 8:65] and on to the towns of Zedad,

16.verse: Berothah, and Sibraim on the border between Damascus [capital of Aram (Syria)] and Hamath [city 120 miles north of Damascus]. Then it will go on to the town of Hazer Hatticon on the border of the country of Hauran.

17.verse: So the border line will go from the ·Mediterranean Sea [Sea] east to the town of Hazar Enan, where the land belonging to Damascus and Hamath lies on the north side. This will be the north side of the land.

18.verse: “On the east side the border runs south from a point between Hauran and Damascus. It will go along the Jordan between Gilead and the land of Israel and will continue to the town of Tamar [probaby En-Gedi; 2 Chr. 20:2] on the ·Dead [eastern] Sea. This will be the east side of the land.

19.verse: “On the south side the border line will go west from Tamar all the way to the waters of Meribah Kadesh [likely Kadesh Barnea (Num. 34:4), fifty miles south of Beersheba]. Then it will run along the brook of Egypt to the ·Mediterranean [Great] Sea. This will be the south side of the land.

20.verse: “On the west side the ·Mediterranean [Great] Sea will be the ·border line [boundary] up to a place across from Lebo Hamath [v. 15]. This will be the west side of your land.

21.verse: “You will divide this land among the tribes of Israel.

22.verse: You will divide it as ·family property [an inheritance] for yourselves and for the foreigners who live and have children among you. You are to treat these foreigners the same as people born in Israel; they are to ·share the land [be allotted an inheritance] with the tribes of Israel.

23.verse: In whatever tribe the foreigner lives, you will give him ·some land [his inheritance],” says the Lord GOD.

1.verse: Dividing the Land - “These are the ·areas of the tribes named here [names of the tribes]: Dan will have one share at the northern border. It will go from the sea through Hethlon to Lebo Hamath [47:15], all the way to Hazar Enan [47:17], ·where Damascus lies to the north. It will stop there next to Hamath [or …which is located on the northern border of Damascus next to Hamath]. This will be Dan’s northern border from the east side to the ·Mediterranean Sea on the west side [west].

2.verse: “·South of [Beside] Dan’s border, Asher will have one share. It will go from the east side to the west side.

3.verse: “·South of [Beside] Asher’s border, Naphtali will have one share. It will go from the east side to the west side.

4.verse: “·South of [Beside] Naphtali’s border, Manasseh will have one share. It will go from the east side to the west side.

5.verse: “·South of [Beside] Manasseh’s border, Ephraim will have one share. It will go from the east side to the west side.

6.verse: “·South of [Beside] Ephraim’s border, Reuben will have one share. It will go from the east side to the west side.

7.verse: “·South of [Beside] Reuben’s border, Judah will have one share. It will go from the east side to the west side.

8.verse: “·South of [Beside] Judah’s border will be the ·holy area which you are to give [portion set apart]. It will be ·about seven miles [twenty-five thousand cubits] wide and as long and wide as one of the tribes’ shares. It will run from the east side to the west side. The ·Temple [sanctuary] will be in the middle of this area.

9.verse: “The share which you will give the LORD will be ·about seven miles [twenty-five thousand cubits] long and ·three miles [ten thousand cubits] wide.

10.verse: The ·holy area [sacred allotment] will be divided among these people. The priests will have land ·about seven miles [twenty-five thousand cubits] long on the north and south sides, and ·three miles [ten thousand cubits] wide on the west and east sides. The ·Temple [sanctuary] of the LORD will be in the middle of it.

11.verse: This land is for the ·priests who are given the holy duty of serving the LORD [consecrated priests]. ·They […who] are the ·descendants [sons] of Zadok who ·did my work [were faithful to me; kept my charge] and did not ·leave me [go astray] when Israel and the Levites ·left me [went astray].

12.verse: They will have as their share a very holy part of the holy portion of the land. It will be next to the land of the Levites.

13.verse: “Alongside the land for the priests, the Levites will have a share ·about seven miles [twenty-five thousand cubits] long and ·three miles [ten thousand cubits] wide; its full length will be ·about seven miles [twenty-five thousand cubits] and its full width ·about three miles [ten thousand cubits].

14.verse: The Levites are not to sell or ·trade [exchange] any of this land. They are not to ·let anyone else own [transfer; alienate] any of this best part of the land, because it ·belongs [is set apart/holy] to the LORD.

15.verse: City Property - “The rest of the area will be ·about one and one-half miles [five thousand cubits] wide and ·seven miles [twenty-five thousand cubits] long. It will ·not be holy but [be for common use and] will belong to the city and be used for homes and pastures. The city will be in the middle of it.

16.verse: These are the city’s measurements: the north side will be ·about one mile [four thousand five hundred cubits], the south side ·about one mile [four thousand five hundred cubits], the east side ·about one mile [four thousand five hundred cubits], and the west side ·about one mile [four thousand five hundred cubits].

17.verse: The city’s land for pastures will be ·about four hundred thirty-seven feet [two hundred fifty cubits] on the north, ·four hundred thirty-seven feet [two hundred fifty cubits] on the south, ·four hundred thirty-seven feet [two hundred fifty cubits] on the east, and ·four hundred thirty-seven feet [two hundred fifty cubits] on the west.

18.verse: Along the long side of the holy area there will be left ·three miles [ten thousand cubits] on the east and ·three miles [ten thousand cubits] on the west. It will be used to grow food for the city workers.

19.verse: The city workers from all the tribes of Israel will farm this land.

20.verse: This whole area will be square, ·seven miles [twenty-five thousand cubits] by ·seven miles [twenty-five thousand cubits]. You shall give to the LORD the holy share along with the city property.

21.verse: “Land that is left over on both sides of the holy area and city property will belong to the ·ruler [prince]. That land will extend eastward from the ·seven miles [twenty-five thousand cubits] of the holy area to the eastern border and westward from the ·seven miles [twenty-five thousand cubits] to the ·Mediterranean Sea [western border]. Both of these areas run the length of the lands of the tribes, and they belong to the ·ruler [prince]. The holy area with the ·Holy Place [sanctuary] of the ·Temple [house] will be in the middle.

22.verse: The Levites’ land and the city property will be in the middle of the lands belonging to the ·ruler [prince]. Those lands will be between Judah’s border and Benjamin’s border.

23.verse: The Other Tribes’ Land - “Here is what the rest of the tribes will receive: Benjamin will have one share. It will go from the east side to the ·Mediterranean Sea on the west side [west side].

24.verse: “·South of [Beside] Benjamin’s land, Simeon will have one share. It will go from the east side to the west side.

25.verse: “·South of [Beside] Simeon’s land, Issachar will have one share. It will go from the east side to the west side.

26.verse: “·South of [Beside] Issachar’s land, Zebulun will have one share. It will go from the east side to the west side.

27.verse: “·South of [Beside] Zebulun’s land, Gad will have one share. It will go from the east side to the west side.

28.verse: “The southern border of Gad’s land will go ·east from Tamar on the Dead Sea [from Tamar; 47:18] to the waters of Meribah Kadesh [47:19]. Then it will run along the brook of Egypt to the ·Mediterranean [Great] Sea.

29.verse: “This is the land you will divide among the tribes of Israel to be their shares,” says the Lord GOD.

30.verse: The Gates of the City - “These will be the ·outside borders [or exits] of the city: The north side will measure ·more than one mile [four thousand five hundred cubits].

31.verse: There will be three gates facing north: Reuben’s Gate, Judah’s Gate, and Levi’s Gate, named for the tribes of Israel.

32.verse: “The east side will measure ·more than one mile [four thousand five hundred cubits]. There will be three gates facing east: Joseph’s Gate, Benjamin’s Gate, and Dan’s Gate.

33.verse: “The south side will measure ·more than one mile [four thousand five hundred cubits]. There will be three gates facing south: Simeon’s Gate, Issachar’s Gate, and Zebulun’s Gate.

34.verse: “The west side will measure ·more than one mile [four thousand five hundred cubits]. There will be three gates facing west: Gad’s Gate, Asher’s Gate, and Naphtali’s Gate.

35.verse: “The city will measure ·about six miles around [eighteen thousand cubits]. From then on the name of the city will be The LORD Is There.”
